QuLTRA
  • QuLTRA vs QuCAT
  • View page source

QuLTRA vs QuCATÔÉÅ

Here, we compare the results obtained with QuLTRA and QuCAT to demonstrate that, for lumped-element structures, both tools yield consistent and equivalent outcomes.

The first structure consists of a simple qubit coupled to an LC resonator.

[18]:

import qucat
import qultra as qu
import numpy as np
Cj=90e-15
Lj=8e-9
Cg=5e-15
Cr=70e-15
Lr=8e-9

[3]:

qucat_netlist=[qucat.C(0,1,Cj),qucat.J(0,1,Lj),qucat.C(1,2,Cg),qucat.C(0,2,Cr),qucat.L(0,2,Lr)]
qucat_circuit=qucat.Network(qucat_netlist)

qucat_circuit.f_k_A_chi(pretty_print=True)

         mode |       freq.  |       diss.  |       anha.  |
            0 |     5.74 GHz |          0Hz |      181 MHz |
            1 |     6.55 GHz |          0Hz |      731 kHz |

Kerr coefficients (diagonal = Kerr, off-diagonal = cross-Kerr)
         mode |         0    |         1    |
            0 |      181 MHz |              |
            1 |       23 MHz |      731 kHz |


[3]:

(array([5.73762268e+09, 6.54921303e+09]),
 array([0., 0.]),
 array([1.80694237e+08, 7.31150673e+05]),
 array([[1.80694237e+08, 2.29882329e+07],
        [2.29882329e+07, 7.31150673e+05]]))

[4]:

qultra_netlist=[qu.C(0,1,Cj),qu.J(0,1,Lj),qu.C(1,2,Cg),qu.C(0,2,Cr),qu.L(0,2,Lr)]

qultra_circuit=qu.QCircuit(qultra_netlist,4,7)
qultra_circuit.show_all()

+------+------------+----------+
| Mode | Freq [GHz] | k [MHz]  |
+------+------------+----------+
|  1   |  5.74e+00  | 0.00e+00 |
|  2   |  6.55e+00  | 0.00e+00 |
+------+------------+----------+
Chi matrix [MHz]:
+------+----------+----------+
| Mode |    1     |    2     |
+------+----------+----------+
|  1   | 1.81e+02 | 2.30e+01 |
|  2   | 2.30e+01 | 7.31e-01 |
+------+----------+----------+

Another structure that we can compare is the microwave band-pass filter presented in the appendix of the original QuCAT paper.

After constructing the structure, we calculate the dissipation rates.

[2]:

RL=50
C=1e-12 #filter capacitance
L=100e-9 #filter inductance
C1=100e-15 #resonator capacitance
L1=10e-9 #resonator inductance

[16]:

qucat_netlist=[qucat.R(0,1,RL),qucat.L(1,2,L),qucat.C(0,2,C),qucat.L(2,3,L),qucat.C(0,3,C),qucat.C(3,4,C1),qucat.L(0,4,L1)]
qucat_circuit=qucat.Network(qucat_netlist)
k=qucat_circuit.loss_rates()
print(k)


[5.63805694e+07 2.31968965e+07 5.71755657e+00]

[15]:

qultra_netlist=[qu.R(0,1,RL),qu.L(1,2,L),qu.C(0,2,C),qu.L(2,3,L),qu.C(0,3,C),qu.C(3,4,C1),qu.L(0,4,L1)]
qultra_circuit=qu.QCircuit(qultra_netlist,0.1,10)
k=qultra_circuit.kappa()
k = [kappa / 1e6 for kappa in k] #convert to Hz
print(k) #Hz

[5.6380569378219546e-05, 2.3196896450171568e-05, 5.717556554390927e-12]

In the original QuCAT paper, an example is provided that shows how to model a multimode resonator. In particular, QuCAT allows one to model a multimode resonator by applying Foster‚Äôs reactance theorem, representing it as a series of LC circuits. The example shown below is taken from the paper and analyzes a qubit coupled to a \(\lambda/4\) resonator in the ultra-strong coupling regime. The corresponding QuCAT code is also reproduced from the original publication.

[26]:

f0=4.603e9
w0=f0*2*np.pi

Z0=50
Ej=18.15e9
Cc=40.3e-15

Cj=5.13e-15
C0=np.pi/4/w0/Z0
L0=4*Z0/np.pi/w0

netlist=[qucat.J(12,1,Ej,use_E=True),qucat.C(12,1,Cj), qucat.C(1,2,Cc)]
for m in range(10):
    node_minus=2+m
    node_plus=(2+m+1)
    Lm=L0/(2*m+1)**2

    netlist=netlist+[qucat.L(node_minus,node_plus,Lm),qucat.C(node_minus,node_plus,C0)]

mmusc=qucat.Network(netlist)
print('The qubit frequency is: ',mmusc.eigenfrequencies()[1]/1e9)
print('The qubit anharmonicity is: ',mmusc.anharmonicities()[1]/1e6)

The qubit frequency is:  8.0352410953173
The qubit anharmonicity is:  357.3988610200252

[25]:

e = 1.60217657e-19  # electron charge
h = 6.62606957e-34  # Plank's

phi0=h/(2*e)
Lj=(phi0/(2*np.pi))**2/Ej/h

fr=4.603e9
c=3e8
eps_eff=(11.9+1)/2
l=c/np.sqrt(eps_eff)/fr/4 #resonator length

net=[qu.C(0,1,Cj),qu.J(0,1,Lj),qu.C(1,2,Cc),qu.CPW(2,0,l)]
circuit=qu.QCircuit(net,1,10)
circuit.show_all()

+------+------------+----------+
| Mode | Freq [GHz] | k [MHz]  |
+------+------------+----------+
|  1   |  4.37e+00  | 0.00e+00 |
|  2   |  8.02e+00  | 0.00e+00 |
+------+------------+----------+
Chi matrix [MHz]:
+------+----------+----------+
| Mode |    1     |    2     |
+------+----------+----------+
|  1   | 1.97e-01 | 1.67e+01 |
|  2   | 1.67e+01 | 3.52e+02 |
+------+----------+----------+

The qubit frequency and anharmonicity values differ slightly because QuCAT relies on an approximation that becomes more accurate as the number of LC oscillators in the circuit increases, while in QuLTRA the transmission line is modeled exactly
